arch:property.oc:show_val: Hearth pit in south part of trench; composed of mudbrick- like material with no brick lines underlying burnt surface 2065 and integrated into stones of hearth 2068. Renamed L2073 along with 2068 (i.e., 2068 + 2062 = 2073); Hypothesis is that this fill was created by dirt kicked / tossed onto the fire in the hearth, which over time built up into the thick entity that is our L2062 / 2073 hearth. This hypothesis would explain the charcoal bits evenly dispersed throughout the hard packed very fine silty soil that has no indication at all of brick lines.
this locus closed because it has been integrated into L2073 along with L2068 as one hearth system.
hard, densely packed soil with charcoal chunks dispersed throughout
soil filling fire pit / floor oven (2073)

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area A / Trench 2 / Locus 2062 (Locus)
